    • Method Detail

      • constraintUpdateNotification

        public void constraintUpdateNotification()

      • optimizeLimitingAxes

        public void optimizeLimitingAxes()
        This function should be called after you've set all of the Limiting Cones for this Kusudama. It will orient the axes relative to which constrained rotations are computed so as to minimize the potential for undesirable twist rotations due to antipodal singularities. In general, auto-optimization attempts to point the y-component of the constraint axes in the direction that places it within an oreintation allowed by the constraint, and roughly as far as possible from any orientations not allowed by the constraint.

        Snaps the bone this Kusudama is constraining to be within the Kusudama's orientational and axial limits.

      • setPainfullness

        public void setPainfullness(float amt)
        A value between (ideally between 0 and 1) dictating how much the bone to which this kusudama belongs prefers to be away from the edges of the kusudama if it can. This is useful for avoiding unnatural poses, as the kusudama will push bones back into their more "comfortable" regions. Leave this value at its default of 0 unless you empircal observations show you need it. Setting this value to anything higher than 0.4 is probably overkill in most situations.
        Parameters:
        amt -

      • getPainfullness

        public float getPainfullness()
        Returns:
        A value between (ideally between 0 and 1) dictating how much the bone to which this kusudama belongs prefers to be away from the edges of the kusudama if it can.

      • setAxialLimits

        public void setAxialLimits(float minAngle,
                           float inRange)
        Kusudama constraints decompose the bone orientation into a swing component, and a twist component. The "Swing" component is the final direction of the bone. The "Twist" component represents how much the bone is rotated about its own final direction. Where limit cones allow you to constrain the "Swing" component, this method lets you constrain the "twist" component.
        Parameters:
        minAnlge - some angle in radians about the major rotation frame's y-axis to serve as the first angle within the range that the bone is allowed to twist.
        inRange - some angle in radians added to the minAngle. if the bone's local Z goes maxAngle radians beyond the minAngle, it is considered past the limit. This value is always interpreted as being in the positive direction. For example, if this value is -PI/2, the entire range from minAngle to minAngle + 3PI/4 is considered valid.

      • snapToTwistLimits

        public float snapToTwistLimits(AbstractAxes toSet,
                               AbstractAxes limitingAxes)
        Parameters:
        toSet -
        limitingAxes -
        Returns:
        radians of twist required to snap bone into twist limits (0 if bone is already in twist limits)

      • pointInLimits

        public <V extends Vec3f<?>> Vec3f<?> pointInLimits(V inPoint,
                                                   float[] inBounds,
                                                   AbstractAxes limitingAxes)
        Given a point (in global coordinates), checks to see if a ray can be extended from the Kusudama's origin to that point, such that the ray in the Kusudama's reference frame is within the range allowed by the Kusudama's coneLimits. If such a ray exists, the original point is returned (the point is within the limits). If it cannot exist, the tip of the ray within the kusudama's limits that would require the least rotation to arrive at the input point is returned.
        Parameters:
        inPoint - the point to test.
        returns - a number from -1 to 1 representing the point's distance from the boundary, 0 means the point is right on the boundary, 1 means the point is within the boundary and on the path furthest from the boundary. any negative number means the point is outside of the boundary, but does not signify anything about how far from the boundary the point is.
        Returns:
        the original point, if it's in limits, or the closest point which is in limits.

      • pointOnPathSequence

        public <V extends Vec3f<?>> Vec3f<?> pointOnPathSequence(V inPoint,

      • addLimitCone

        public void addLimitCone(SGVec_3f newPoint,
                         float radius,
                         AbstractLimitCone previous,
                         AbstractLimitCone next)
        Add a LimitCone to the Kusudama.
        Parameters:
        newPoint - where on the Kusudama to add the LimitCone (in Kusudama's local coordinate frame defined by its bone's majorRotationAxes))
        radius - the radius of the limitCone
        previous - the LimitCone adjacent to this one (may be null if LimitCone is not supposed to be between two existing LimitCones)
        next - the other LimitCone adjacent to this one (may be null if LimitCone is not supposed to be between two existing LimitCones)

      • removeLimitCone

        public void removeLimitCone(AbstractLimitCone limitCone)

        public abstract AbstractLimitCone createLimitConeForIndex(int insertAt,
                                                          Vec3f<?> newPoint,
                                                          float radius)

      • addLimitConeAtIndex

        public void addLimitConeAtIndex(int insertAt,
                                SGVec_3f newPoint,
                                float radius)
        Adds a LimitCone to the Kusudama. LimitCones are reach cones which can be arranged sequentially. The Kusudama will infer a smooth path leading from one LimitCone to the next. Using a single LimitCone is functionally equivalent to a classic reachCone constraint.
        Parameters:
        insertAt - the intended index for this LimitCone in the sequence of LimitCones from which the Kusudama will infer a path. @see IK.AbstractKusudama.limitCones limitCones array.
        newPoint - where on the Kusudama to add the LimitCone (in Kusudama's local coordinate frame defined by its bone's majorRotationAxes))
        radius - the radius of the limitCone

      • getRotationalFreedom

        public float getRotationalFreedom()
        TODO: // this functionality is not yet fully implemented It always returns an overly simplistic representation not in line with what is described below.
        Specified by:
        getRotationalFreedom in interface Constraint
        Returns:
        an (approximate) measure of the amount of rotational freedom afforded by this kusudama, with 0 meaning no rotational freedom, and 1 meaning total unconstrained freedom. This is approximately computed as a ratio between the orientations the bone can be in vs the orientations it cannot be in. Note that unfortunately this function float counts the orientations a bone can be in between two limit cones in a sequence if those limit cones intersect with a previous sequence.

      • attachTo

        public void attachTo(AbstractBone forBone)
        attaches the Kusudama to the BoneExample. If the kusudama has its own limiting axes specified, replaces the bone's major rotation axes with the Kusudamas limiting axes. otherwise, this function will set the kusudama's limiting axes to the major rotation axes specified by the bone.
        Parameters:
        forBone - the bone to which to attach this Kusudama.

      • setStrength

        public void setStrength(float newStrength)
        for IK solvers. Defines the weight ratio between the unconstrained IK solved orientation and the constrained orientation for this bone per iteration. This should help stabilize solutions somewhat by allowing for soft constraint violations.
        Parameters:
        strength - a value between 0 and 1. Any other value will be clamped to this range.

      • getStrength

        public float getStrength()
        for IK solvers. Defines the weight ratio between the unconstrained IK solved orientation and the constrained orientation for this bone per iteration. This should help stabilize solutions somewhat by allowing for soft constraint violations.
